column4: what does: "iwl3945: Radio Frequency Kill Switch is On: Kill switch must be turned off for wireless networking to work." mean?
it usually means that you have a button on your computer that enables wifi and is currently set to "off"
thanks yes I have a button but did change it in this moent, for the full log please see: http://paste.ubuntu.com/162509/
have you a clue for my problem? http://paste.ubuntu.com/162509/
you may have to turn your wireless on before Ubuntu boots
it's turned on before boot, it just seems to fall out from time to time while using it
you may also have to create an options.conf file in /etc/modprobe.d that contains a line with the name of your wireless driver module and 'rf_kill=0'
this piece of f... s... disconnected againsoundray, this piece of f... s... disconnected again
don't let your frustration ruin your good manners.
so do you have any other clue?
there might be other options to the iwl3945 driver that might help
I still think that rfkill=1 or rfkill=0 might help (or it might be rf_kill)
so the /etc/modprobe.d/options.conf should be changed again?
actually it's neither: check modinfo iwl3945, it's 'disable=0'
yes, that's where you feed options to the driver.
: should I first delete your previous attemp?
you can do that, or try a combination of options
I'm sorry but this is far to complex for me ;-)
that's just a self-limiting belief you are holding ;)
ok thanks for your help to this point, but it has gone late now maybe I'll come back later days to fix the issue
okay, good luck
